text:
is it possible to do something along these lines in franklin?
```{{ for item in load_items("items.json") }}
   @@myitem
      **{{ item.title }}**
      {{ item.text }}
      ![]({{ item.image }})
   @@
{{ end }}```

elements.text: is it possible to do something along these lines in franklin?
in this particular case, the easiest is to write a hfun that generates the HTML:
{{load_my_items}}
in utils.jl

function hfun_load_my_items() io = IOBuffer() for item in load_items("items.json") write(io, """
$(item.title) $(item.text)$
""") end return String(take!(io)) end

text: (I'm assuming you have the function `load_items` defined somewhere)

elements.text: (I'm assuming you have the function
load_items
defined somewhere)

text: here's something you might find more useful than the docs: <http://franklinjl.org/demos/#001_how_to_load_data_from_file_and_loop_over_rows>

elements.text: here's something you might find more useful than the docs:

text: Oh, didn't look into the demos section a lot

elements.text: Oh, didn't look into the demos section a lot

text:
Final note: if you'd find it easier to describe the items using Markdown, you can also do it using a `lxfun` instead of a `hfun` the idea is the same except that the output of a `lxfun` is markdown that gets re-processed by Franklin. The syntax calling it is different, it'd be:
```\load_my_items{}```
the rest would be the same (see <https://franklinjl.org/syntax/utils/>)

text: but I think if you don't like the idea of writing Julia code to generate custom MD or HTML then Franklin might disappoint you a lot; that's basically a core idea :smile:

elements.text: but I think if you don't like the idea of writing Julia code to generate custom MD or HTML then Franklin might disappoint you a lot; that's basically a core idea

text: the issue with expanding a mustache-language with the likes of `filter` `pass` and what not is that it quickly becomes complicated to maintain while always falling short of what just calling Julia would do; so now you could do some parsing of the mustache and feed it to Julia but that's actually not as simple to do as it might seem; it could be made more sophisticated but you're the first one asking for it :slightly_smiling_face:

text: sure, I'm not for expanding the template language artificially

elements.text: sure, I'm not for expanding the template language artificially

text: I'm all for using julia - like mako does for python

elements.text: I'm all for using julia - like mako does for python

text: it allows basically any code in templates

elements.text: it allows basically any code in templates

text: and using the host language as-is in templates feels like less "reinventing the wheel" than special template languages like the one in franklin (and many others written in many languages)

elements.text: and using the host language as-is in templates feels like less "reinventing the wheel" than special template languages like the one in franklin (and many others written in many languages)

text: btw I'm always open to considering adding stuff that might help people get shit done so if you feel like you have a clear idea of something additional that could be done in Franklin that would make your life easier, please open an issue on GitHub and we can discuss the details :slightly_smiling_face:

text:
I don't judge in either "+" or "-" as I didn't really use franklin (yet?)
till now I only worked with python template engines, and by far preferred those that allow arbitrary code in templates (e.g. mako) to those that use some specially crafted sublanguage there (e.g. jinja)
but this preference is clearly subjective because both kinds have lots of users

text: yeah no worries, I'll have a bit more of a look at mako, see how they disambiguate between python and HTML and see whether we can support some of this; for now I have a feeling that the way things are currently done are a bit easier in Franklin because you get an actual julia file with syntax highlighting etc + you can test the functions
